items: Understand what the terminal (or shell) is
Learn the basic structure of a terminal prompt
Become familiar with common first commands

sections.heading: What is the Terminal?
paragraphs: The terminal is where you type commands to control Linux.
Also called the shell, it allows you to interact with the system using text instead of a graphical interface.

sections.heading: Terminal Prompt
paragraphs: computer → the name of your computer
$ → indicates the terminal is ready to accept a command

sections.heading: First Commands
rows: Print working directory (shows where you are)
List files and folders in the current directory
Go back to the previous directory
Show a list of commands you typed previously

sections.text: Commands are case-sensitive! Always type them exactly.

sections.heading: Practice
steps: List the files in your current directory: ls
Navigate into a folder (e.g., Documents): cd Documents
Go back to the previous directory: cd ..

sections.heading: Key Terms
rows: Symbol that shows the terminal is ready for commands
Instruction you type into the terminal

sections.text: The terminal is one of the most powerful tools in Linux, and many Linux experts do almost everything through it!

bullets: The terminal is a text-based interface to control Linux.
The prompt shows your username, computer name, and current directory.
Basic commands like pwd, ls, cd, clear, and history help you navigate and explore Linux.
